rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in polymerization.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One ot the outstanding topics of Organic Chemistry at present is that of polymerization. It is important first of all from the purely scientific point of view, as a reaction met with in natural processes and in laboratory experience, the mechanism of which is still obscure. From the point of view of commerc1al application also, the subject of polymerization is of great interest. There may be mentioned the elucidation or the constitution of such highly important naturally occuring substances as rubber and cellulose; its daily use in the petro1eum industry; its recent application to synthetic lacquers and resina, etc. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Haemolytic jaundice, with special reference to icterusneonatorum.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Icterus neonatorum has always been a favourite subjeot for discussion and the literature on the subject is tremendous. It would therefore seem unnecessary to write a new paper onicterus neonatorum. The object of this paper however is to bring the explanation of the phenomenon of icterus neonatorwm in accordance with the modern views on icterus in general and with the haemolytic type especially. In the last twenty years radical changes have been made,in regard to the conception of the pathogenesis of the various forms of icterus. These new ideas only slowly have gained entrance into the explanatlon of the physiological icterus occuring in the new born. An attempt is made here to explain the phenomenon of icterus neonatorum on the basis of the modern conception of icterus in general.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of fine structure on the Stark components of Ha.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Stark effect was discovered in the Balmer series by (1) J.S. Stark (Fig.l.) in October 1913. In this series the effect appears to be perfectly symmetrical, just as the Zeeman effect is in all spectra. The initial theoretical explanation by Epstein left this symmetry intact, and pictured all hydrogen levels as split by the field into evenly spaced sub-levels {Fig.2.}. Taking this view of the subject there appears to be little connection with the Stark effect in ail other spectra, where it is characterised by the appearance of new combination lines and asymmetric displacements of the energy levels. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Action of sulphurous acid and bisulphites on cellulose.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is well known that acids, elkalies, and reagenta of various kinds, reset with cellulose in different ways end to varying degrees. However the action, in many cases, is one of "degradation". By the term "degradation" is meant a decreaae in tha polymerized or associated state of the cellulose aggregate aa indicated, among other factors, by a decrease in the viscosity of a solution of the cellulose in cuprammonium hydroxide. A change in properties of the cellulosic material alwaya accompanies this degradation and the extent of the change is dependent upon the extent to which the cellulose aggregate is depolymerized. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An Investigation of the equilibria existing in gas-water systems forming electrolytes.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The data and theoretical treatment contained in this thesis is the continuation of a series of researches instituted to investigate the equilibria existing in oertain gaseous-aqueous systems. In this work the vapor pressures and electrolytic conductivities of aqueous solutions of sulphur dioxide, carbon dioxide, and ammonia have been measured with greater precision than ever before over a temperature range from 0 c. to 25 C. degress and over a concentration range where their respective vapor pressures do not exceed one atmosphere. From the data thns derived, equilibria relations have been calcula ted and certain changes have been made in the mode of theoretical prooedure involved in this type of calculation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Old age pension legislation in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Among the delusions common to humanity is the belief that old age is a remote liability, the consideration of which may be indefinitely post-poned. Death is accepted as inevitable, but old age is forever being put off and denied like a poor relation whom one chooses not to recognise. At the same time, the dread of old age is as universal as the fear of death. A man may fortify himself against the fear of death by his religion or his philosophy. But where the prospect of old age is concerned, the possession or an assured income is more effective in calming the fears of men than many volumes or philosophy. The study of old age as it effects income, and of an assured income as it effects old age is the purpose of this thesis. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chemical and physiological studies of the parathyroid hormone.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The parathyroid glands have been recognized in all classes of vertebrates with the exception of fishes (1). As a rule there are four distinct glands so situated with regard to the thyroid gland that they have been referred to as the superior or external and the inferior or internal pairs. Sandstrom (2) was the first to describe the superior pair. For some reason or other they were forgotten until eleven years later - 1891 - they were rediscovered by Gley (3). The inferior pair were described by Kohn (4) in 1895. Accessory parathyroid tissue is sometimes present and may be situated in the thorax nearer to or embedded in the thymus gland (1). The parathyroids develop as thickenings of the endoderm of the third and the fourth branchial clefts. The superior pair of glandules is related to the fourth branchial clefts with reference to development while the inferior pair is similarly related to the third branchial clefts. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Christian implications in Beowulf.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: With few exceptions the Christian passages in Beowulf are very short. However, their importance lies not so much in this fact as in their frequency which imparts a truly Christian atmosphere to this heathen poem. None of these allusions tell of Christ, the Atonement, or the miracles, but they are of the Old Testament stories, for example, of Cain, and of the Flood, yet they bear the spirit of Christianity insomuch as even these ideas would not have been familiar topics if the author had not been enlightened by the new faith. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Beowulf.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cellulose ethers.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The structure, preparation and properties ot the Cellulose Ethers have recently became an increasingly important subject for technical and theoretical research. Previous to the last decade these interesting derivatives of cellulose constituted a practically unexplored field. The only ethers which had been at all thoroughly investigated were the methyl and ethyl celluloses, and only theoretical importance was attached to them. They have served to provide, however, in the capable hands ot Irvine, Haworth, and other workers, a most efficient tool for the investigation of the structure of carbohydrates and polysaccharides. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The social ethics of the Prophets.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In writing on the subject of social Ethics of the Prophets, I have given special attention to the Book of Deuteronomy, because it is admitted by all scholars that this book summarises all that is best and most permanent in the ethical teachings of the prophets. Consequently no treatment of the Ethics of the prophets would be adequate which was not focused on the Deuteronomic summary. It is clear that this social legislation is the result of contributions from many sources and writers living in different centuries. This fact makes the subject both extensive and cpmp1icated. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Oriental Languages.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A systematic study of the Genus Mycobacterium.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Lehmann and Neumann (54) first proposed the generic name Mycobacteriumn for the group of acid-fast bacteria, with Mycobacterium tuberculosis - the tubercle bacillus of Koch - as the type species. They mention, however, in a second edition of their work, that Metschnikoff (63) had previously proposed for the tubercle bacilli the generic name of Sclerothrix, with Sclerothrix Kochii for the species of tubercle bacillus. They did not know of this, when they first proposed the name Mycobacterium for the genus, and as Metschnikoff had not accurately defined his new genus, according to the rules of botanical nomenclature, they claim their name of Mycobacterium to be still valid. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Theories of value from David Hume to John Stuart Mill : a critical study.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Kant has argued that being {Das Sein) is not an attribute of objects: for assuming that an object has first been imagined and then endowed with being, it follows that if being is anattribute, the object which is, is different from the imagined object. Since this is not the case, being, therefore, is not an attribute of object. Simmel (1), following Kant, argues similarly about value (Der Wart). The object is the same after it is endowed with value as before. The conclusion, then, is that value is not an attribute of objeots. In this case, value exists only in the psychic make up of the endowing agent. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: La doctrine de I'unanimisme dans les oeuvres de M.Jules Romains.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: La doctrine de l'unanimisme qui marque lea meilleures oeuvres de M. Jules Romains s'explique dans le choix d'un groupe de ges au lieu d'un personnage comme la figure centrale d'un ouvrage. Toute l'histoire. toute l'action principale et tous les caractères se rapportent et tirent leur importance de ce groupe. Comme indique le nom, l'unanimisme exprime la vie d'un groupe consideré comme un seul être, uni et entier. Ce groupe a les qualitée de caractère d'une personne et il reagit à toutes lea influences exterieures comme fait une personne. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Maurice Maeterlinck devant la critique Americaine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Aucun auteur, sans doute, ne fut jamais annoncé au public littéraire avec plus de louanges que Maurtoe Maeterlinck loreque Octave Klrbeau le présenta en cas termes: "Je ne sais rien de M. Maurice Maeterlinck, je ne sais d'ou' il est et comment il est. S'i1 est vieux ou jeune, riche ou pauvre, je ne le sais pas; je sais seulement qu'il aucun homme n'est plus inconnu que lui; et je sais auss1 qu'il a fait un chef d'oeuvre. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Aberrations from the ideal gas laws and a precision method for the determination of the densities of gases.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Measurement" plays the role of modulator and investigator in many branches of science. In general, it seems to be the avocation of a natural philosopher to enunciate laws, and then by measurement to seek exceptions to them. These usually discovered exceptions and failures of applicability more often than not yield conclusions which may overshadow the fundamental generalization itself. This is very well illustrated in the developaent or the so called equations of state for gases, and the general applications of the theoretical statements usually referred to on the whole as the Kinetic Theory of Gases. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cavitation phenomena and the flow in divergingtubes.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: As the title of this thesis indicates there are two problems involved, namely, "Cavitation" and "Divergent Tubes," and although the former may be caused directly by divergence, there are also other causes, so the two problems have been treated separately. In regard to divergent tubes, special attention has been given to their use in connection with reaction water turbines, or as "draft tubes", which is perhaps the most recent and most important development. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hydraulics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The influence of the university on the developmentof drama in the United States and Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The people in the world today are a theatre loving people. Everyone is becoming theatre conscious and the theatre both indirectly and directly is entering everyone's life. The number of theatrical publications, the space devoted to news of the theatre in current periodicals, the great number of amateur groups, organized for the production and study of drama, the interest of the university in providing oourses dealing with the drama both theoretically and practically, not to mention the ever-present professional stage, all testify to what a great extent the interest of the public in dramatic affairs has grown. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The attitude of the Roman satirists towardsforeigners.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is no idle assertion that in practically every field of literary composition the Greeks provided the Romans with highly finished models on which to fashion their efforts. Satire, however, the Romans accepted as an independent creation o£ their own; Quintilian says, "Satura quidem tota nostra est,"(l} and considering Quintilian's learning, sensibilityand position in Roman literature, it would not be incorrect to accept his remark as the general opinion held among the literary classes at Rome concerning the origin of satire, and as a well-founded statement for critics of our own day to follow. If, then, we accept Quintilian's statement we must not assume that the Romans were the first to make use of personal invective which is the life and blood of satire. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Latin.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L'Alsace-Lorraine dans le roman français entre les deuxguerres.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: L'Alsace-Lorraine, dans ce que 1'on pourrait hardiment nommer leur destin légal, ne connurent que 1'insécurité. Ce sont des terres prédesttinées aux combats, designées pour êtretour é tour 1'otage abandonné par le vaincu, le bastion nécessaire au vainqueur. Le peuple de l'Alsace-Lorraine fut enraciné à un sol dont la richasse fit tout ensemble sa prosperité et son infortune. La' où 1es légions romaines élevèrent jadis leurs camps et 1eurs ramparts, 1es guerriers de l'Occident necessèrent de porter leurs armes que pour de courtes trêves. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L'influence françise sur les poètes hispano-américains de I'école 'modernista'.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Le Mouvement Modernista, peut-être le mouvement le plus important de la poésie hispano-américaine, eut son origine en même temps en Colombia {Silva), à Cuba (Casal) au Nicaragua (Dario) puis dans les autres pays du monde américain et plus tard par Dario en Espagne. Selon Goldberg (1) " e Modernisme. dans sed implications plus larges, n'est pas un phénomène limité aux écrivains castellans et ibero-amérioainsde la dernière partie du l8ème siècle et de la première partie du 20ème, mais c'est una manifestation de l'éspr1t qui inonda le monde intellectual de l'ouest, pendant cette période - Surnbourne, Hanptman, Nietzche, Ibsen, Whitman, d'Annunzio et surtout les parnassiens et des symbolistes en France. Ce fut l'âge de liberté - pour la poesie, pour l'amour, pour la musique et pour la femme - de la 1iberté spirituelle et materielle." [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The history and development of scenery on the English stage from medieval times to the year 1700.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is the purpose of this thesis to trace the development of scenery on the English stage from the beginning of drama in church ritual, to the opening of the eighteenth century, by which time the modern picture-frame stage had become the conventional setting in the theatre. Scenery has two main purposes. These are, first, that of utility, by supplying a background for the action, and by reproducing objects mentioned in the text of the play; and, second, that of art, by the giving of pleasure to the eye as well as the creating of illusion. The combination of these two purposes in a setting makes a production live. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Theaters -- Stage-setting and scenery.
Theater -- England.
English drama -- History and criticism.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Shakespeare’s use of sound and colour.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Drama is the one art that can call upon almost every device of the sister arts. All the various methods by which an artist may express himself are combined in the art of the drama, for it is a blending of literature, painting, dancing, music and sculpture. But, whereas in the past the art of literature alone was emphasized, today the other arts are regarded as equally important in the production of plays. From 1660, when movable scenery was introduced on the stage, to the present day, the art of' the theatre has greatly developed. It wasduring the Restoration period that the picture-frame stage was introduced and with it came many of the elaborate Italian methods of staging. The English theatre retained this form throughout a great part of the eighteenth century, but in the later eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries a passion for realism resulted in an effort to reform the stage. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616 -- Criticism and interpretation.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The initial stresses in welded joints.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Welding is a comparatively new tool in the hands of the structural fabricator. Recent years have witnessed a rapid growth of the welding process as a means of building up and connecting structural members and the possibilities are only beginning to be recognised. There is still a lack of knowledge of the physical characteristics of welded joints. At present this difficulty is overcome by using a large factor of safety. The problem, then, is to determine the distribution of stress in the component parts of the joint. Within the past three years several attempts have been made to solve this problem. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some aspects of the pharmacology of mercury.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although the oral administration of calomel has long been recognized to be of value in ridding the organism of water in cases of cardiac oedema (Jendrassik, 1886 (1) ), the mechanism of this action is still an open question. The experiments herein described were undertaken with the hope of throwing some further light upon the pharmacology of this phenomenon. The results of our studies are considered in respect to both quantitative and qualitative changes in urinary elimination and a comparison is made of the diuresis resulting from the injection of the organic mercury oomplex, novasurol, and that following the inorganic compound, mercuric chloride. Finally, some conclusions are drawn concerningthe mechanism of the process. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Preparation of ethyl acetylene and a determination of some of its physical constants.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of the research described below is the preparation of pure ethyl acetylene and a study of its physical constants including surface tension, density of the liquid, density of the gas, latent heat of vaporization and from this study to correlate the information obtained concerning this four carbon acetylene compound with that already found for the two, three and four carbon compounds of the paraffin, olefine and acetylene series which have already been studied in this laboratory. In 1921 Maass and Wright investigated theproperties of pure ethane, ethylene, propane, propylene, acetylene, and allylene which are the first members of an homologous series of compounds containing two and three carbon atoms. By this investigation the effect on the properties of the compounds by passing from saturation to various degrees of unsaturation was shown. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.
